The project faces considerable risks, many of which cannot be avoided. These risks fall into two broad categories: (a) Political and Institutional Risks: the success of the project requires stability in WBG, steady progress in the bilateral negotiations, and a maturation of internal political processes. It will also require that incentive structures at central and local levels are positive and mutually reinforcing. (b) Managerial and Technical Risks: effective and timely implementation of the project requires the early consideration by the Executive Authority of the Palestinian Council (EAPC), the executive arm of said Council, of measures to strengthen the SMs, MLG and the other implementation agencies, and the early rationalization of PECDAR. Risks would be difficult to manage but would be minimized through dialogue, careful crafting of incentive structures, appropriately targeted technical assistance and close, on-ground supervision in WBG. Poverty Category: The project is not a part of a core poverty programn but will support Palestinian effort to alleviate poverty by creating a significant number of lower skilled jobs at the municipal and village levels where poverty is most widespread. Moreover, improvements to the water and sanitation services will also have a positive impact on reduction of related diseases, which most often affect the poor. BACKGROUND Introduction 1.1 With the signing of the Declaration of Principles between Israei and the Palestinians in September 1993, Gaza became relatively autonomous. As a result of signing the Interim Agreement on September 28, 1995, similar autonomy has now been extended to parts of the West Bank. These agreements open up new opportunities for Palestinian development, but they also pose rnew challenges. Among the more important of the opportunities is the chance to begin systematically to address critical economic, social, institutional and infrastructural problems, including, particularly, the problems of the local government system. The challenge is to do so efficiently and equitably, and in a manner which best promotes long term economic and social development objectives. 1.2 The Economy: The West Bank and Gaza (WBG) comprises some 6,000 sq. k-n and had a population of 2 million in 1994. This population has been growing at the relatively high rate of about 4 percent per annum. Despite some recent positive signs the economy continues to experience severe strain. The decline which began with the onset of the Intifada in 1987 still continues. This has had a considerable negative impact on living standards, and in 1993 it was estimated that about 17 percent of the population of the West Bank and 33 percent of that of Gaza lived in poverty. Tentative estimates for 1994 suggest that while Gross Domestic Product (GDP) grew by 7.3 percent in real terms, Gross National Product (GNP) grew less (3 percent in real terms) due mainly to the continued loss of employment opportunities for Palestinian workers in Israel. Estimates for 1995 suggest real GDP growth of 3.5 percent, but due to further loss in employment opportunities for Palestinian workers in Israel,i' and allowing for population increase, real per capita GNP probably declined by some 7 percent. Also, the already high 20 percent unemployment rate in 1994 is estimated to have risen to 25 percent. This indicates that the positive job creation performance, particularly in residential construction, was insufficient to overcome the impact of repeated Israeli border closures. The prospects for 1996 had appeared somewhat more promising until the recent bombings in Israel. These have led to extended border closings which have had a severely negative impact on economic and social life. Unemployment is now at crisis levels, particularly in Gaza. 1.3 Infrastructure: Years of economic and political dislocation, neglect of local institutions and under-investment in the public sector have contributed significantly to the present grossly inadequate level of infrastructure and services. These levels are now far below those in countries with comparable per capita GNP. For example, average urban water supply is only about 60 liters per capita per day (compared to 115 in Tunisia and 137 in Jordan); in many areas water quality is low; system losses are high; many villages are unserved; and few municipalities have adequate wastewater collection, treatment or disposal systems. The road network density, while typical of countries at similar income levels, has deteriorated to the point where, without immediate rehabilitation, past investments may be completely lost. Some 50 percent of the roads in Gaza are unpaved, and it is estimated 40 percent of the road system in the West Bank is below acceptable service levels. Electricity consumption (680 kWh per capita per year) is low compared to Egypt and Jordan; networks and systems are generally in a poor condition; services are unreliable; street lighting is almost non-existent; and some 138 villages have no services or 1/ About 63,000 job opportunities were lost between 1992 and 1994, and another 23,000 during 1994/95.

In general, infrastructure and services provision is far lower, and networks and facilities are in a far greater state of disrepair in Gaza than in the West Bank. These conditions cannot be significantly and sustainably improved unless urgent attention is paid to rationalizing and strengthening of the local government (LG) system (see Annex 2 for further details). 1.4 Institutions: Following autonomy in the Gaza Strip, the Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO) and the Government of the State of Israel entered into the Agreement on the Gaza Strip and Jericho Area on May 4, 1994, which, among other things, established the Palestinian Authority as its core policy making body, and by the end of May 1994, a full complement of ministries was announced. Since then a major effort has been made to consolidate these ministries and to develop administrative capacity. More recently, separate national agencies have been established to manage the power and water sectors. Earlier (in late 1993), the PLO had established the Palestinian Economic Council for Development and Reconstruction (PECDAR) as the main transitional vehicle for economic policy making, programmning, management and administration. With the development of ministries, PECDAR was expected to have been restructured or absorbed into one or another of the new ministries. This has not happened. Consequently, there is now a considerable lack of clarity regarding roles and responsibilities at the central level. This has slowed institutional consolidation significantly and complicated policy. In October 1995, the jurisdiction of the new Palestinian institutions was extended to the newly autonomous areas in the West Bank. This jurisdiction is expected to widen as the peace process unfolds, with obvious implications for central and local government capacity building. Notwithstanding these difficulties, significant progress has been made in establishing central government institutions, but much remains to be done to develop capacity equal to the enormous task of nation building. 1.5 Apart from LG institutions (discussed separately below), two other sets of institutions play vital roles in the social and economic life of WBG: the UN agencies and the NGO's. Since 1967, the United Nations Relief and Works Agency (UNRWA) has played a critical role in providing housing, health, education, welfare and infrastructural services to refugee families; UNDP and UNICEF, respectively, help deliver water and sanitation, and children's services. Some 900 to 1,000 mostly local NGOs, responding to a political and institutional vacuum, provided a vast array of services, but particularly in the health, housing and higher education sectors. 1.6 Local Government: Historically, LGs have been the cornerstone of Palestinian governance. They have also been key providers of public goods and services in WBG. Municipalities in particular have well-established service delivery and regulatory functions including electricity, water supply, sanitation, solid waste management, local roads, libraries, parks and recreation, fire abatement, slaughter houses, markets, land use planning, building and development approval, and business and professional licensing. The LG system is composed of 31 municipalities, 103 village councils and some 400 villages. The 31 municipalities accounted for more than 62 percent of the total population in 1994. Gaza differs significantly from the West Bank in that it is considerably poorer (per capita GNP in 1994 of US$1,290 vs US$2,190 in the West Bank), is far more highly urbanized and far less fragmented geographically. Its population density is about 10 times that of the West Bank, and three of its five municipalities (Gaza City, Khan Younis and Rafah) account for nearly 75 percent of the total Gaza population of 0.8 million. Furthermore, about 55 percent of Gaza's population reside in refugee camps, a far higher percentage than in the West Bank. Of the 26 municipalities in the West Bank, the three largest (Nablus, Hebron and Ramallah/Al Bireh) account for less than 20 percent of the total West Bank population of 1.2 million, and the median municipality has a population of less than 13,000 persons. This geographical dispersion in the West Bank presents special challenges for governance and the efficient di-livery of public services; so does the concentration of population Gaza, albeit of a different order.

However, Gaza's legal traditions and institutions differ somewhat from those of the West Bank. This is so because in the aftermath of the 1948 War and the establishment of the state of Israel, Gaza came under Egyptian administration while the West Bank became part of Jordan. Following the 1967 War between Israel and its neighbors, both areas came under Israeli occupation, and fell under the jurisdiction of the Israeli Civil Administration (CA). With the advent of autonomy, the Ministry of Local Government (MLG) became responsible for managing the system. Since then MLG has been moving to unify the two systems, clarify its role and consolidating itself. To date its focus has been on preparing for national elections, successfully held in January 1996. However, it has also begun to actively develop managerial systems and has drafted a new LG law for consideration by the Palestinian Council. This draft law (the second of two drafts) or some modified version is expected to be considered by the new Palestinian Council and will form the basis for LG elections due in the latter half of 1996. Unlike the first draft which foresaw a considerable degree of local autonomy, the second draft envisages a considerable degree of centralization (see Annexes 2 and 3 for further details). IDA/Bank Group Strategy 1.11 Since 1993, IDA has been in the forefront of a broadly based donor-supported effort to assist WBG. To this end, and working in close consultation with Palestinian counterparts, in December 1993, IDA developed the 3-year US$1.2 billion Emergency Assistance Program (EAP) which provided the basic investment framework in WBG.4' Ten infrastructure sectors were identified under EAP for priority support (education; health and welfare; power; telecommunications; water, wastewater and sanitation; roads; transport; solid waste; housing; and agriculture), at an estimated cost of $600 million. In support of EAP, IBRD transferred US$50 million from its own surplus into the trust fund for investments in Gaza. To date, two projects have been developed and implemented from the proceeds of the Trust Fund for Gaza (TFG). The first, the 3-year US$128 million Emergency Rehabilitation Project (ERP, FY94)- -a forerunner of the currently proposed project--focussed on the rehabilitation of basic infrastructure and services in four sectors: roads; water and wastewater, education and power. The ERP was supported by a US$30 million trust fund credit from TFG and became effective in September 1994. After a somewhat difficult start due to local political and managerial problems (including prolonged border closures) and some cofinancing shortfalls, it is now being satisfactorily implemented. The second project, the US$126 million Education and Health Rehabilitation Project (EHRP, FY96), was supported by the remaining US$20 million from TFG. EHRP became effective in September 1995, and is now in the early stages of implementation. Given the substantial size of the originally identified Palestinian investment program (numerous sub-projects estimated at US$600 million) and the limited available time, data and financial resources, it was critical to establish a feasible system for screening proposed projects to derive a refined list. The strategy adopted was to establish a hierarchy of filters through which proposals would have to pass in order to be accepted and an efficient process by which to carry out the review (See Annex 18 for a detailed discussion of the economic analysis methodology and results). Thefirstfilter was the state of preparation of the projects; only projects that would be ready for implementation within 18 months were considered. These filters reduced the size of the proposed program to be evaluated by the Bank to US$260 million--still considerably beyond available resources. The next filter was an acceptable economic rate of return (ERR). The minimum ERR was set at 14 percent; the cost of capital for WBG is estimated by the Country Economist at 10 percent, however, given the large number of projects proposed, it was desirable to raise the hurdle to ensure that the highest value cohort would be considered for further analyses. The investments under the Rehabilitation and Improvement sub-component which represents 60 percent of total project cost thus have been selected to ensure a minimum of 14 percent ERR. 4.3 The analysis involved the development and testing of three analytic approaches (for water, wastewater and roads) that enabled rapid classification and testing of proposals. The issues regarding the development of the local government system in WBG are, in one important respect, unique. The more usual situation that countries face is the existence of a well- established central government structure and the need to create functioning local ?overnments. In WBG, municipal governments and village councils have been in operation over the past three decades and a central government is just currently being created. In conventional circumstances, the role and responsibility of central government and its agencies are already defined and operational, and reform of central-local systems means some form of decentralization in which weak local entities would hope to receive increased powers and respons;bilities. In WBG, currently weak central ministries are trying to define their roles and authority and see the process as one of asserting controi over the pre-existing local bodies. This situation is aggravated by the current circumstances in which the EAPC is not yet fully in charge of the country, do not have the full complement of governing instruments, are dependent on donors for all development expenditures and some recurrent support, and in which the donors frequently make independent arrangements with local authorities

 Annex 6 Page 1 of 4 WEST BANK AND GAZA MUNICIPAL INFRASTRUCTURE DEVELOPMENT PROJECT Maintenance Sub-Program Introduction 1. Almost three decades of inadequate resources have led to the neglect of maintenance of infrastructure in WBG. Facing budget constraints and the requirement to balance budgets, municipalities in WBG have over many years limited maintenance activities mainly to urgent expenditures to respond to breakdowns or severe diminution of services. Annex 2 (Local Government Issues and Strategy) noted the low level of expenditure compared to general norms. However, the problems of maintenance has not been limited to finance; planning, programming and management of maintenance also have been neglected. These systems now need to be rehabilitated in order that benefits from existing infrastructure assets as well as the substantial new investments currently programmed, may be fully realized. This component is designed to pilot the design and implementation of local infrastructure maintenance programs in the selected municipalities and to extend the lessons into the structuring and implementation of programs of maintenance for local infrastructure throughout WBG. Developing and Managing the Program 2. The selected municipalities (SMs) each will establish a working group (WG) led by the head of the technical department, and including the heads of all infrastructure services in the municipalities. This WG will be responsible for overseeing the design and implementation of this program (Annex 8). The WG will be supported, as required, by consultants financed under this project. 3. In preparing this component, it was recognized that the development and implementation of a system for maintenance would be facilitated if a successful working model could be found that could readily be adapted to the realities of the WBG situation. As a result, it was determined to assess whether a model of a successful program may be identified within proximity to WBG. A model which met these considerations was identified in the Arab-managed municipality of Nazareth, in Israel. This successful program has been developed and implemented over the past five years, indicating that a long gestation period for the implementation of a similar system in WBG should not be necessary. In addition, the managers of the program in Nazareth expressed interest in assisting the WBG SMs by providing information, experiences and expertise to municipalities. Costs associated with the assistance provided by Nazareth will be supported by the project. The approach that has been adopted for the development of the WBG maintenance program, therefore, has been based on the systems that are operating in Nazareth. It is anticipated that differences in the current availability of data and resources, and the need to begin to implement improvements as soon as possible, will result in adaptations of this model. However, the principles which underlay its operations are expected to be robust. 4. The process of developing the programs in the SMs will begin, after the formation of the WGs, with a request to the Nazareth Mayor for that city to participate in assisting in this process. On agreement on the modalities, each SM will hold a workshop with the Nazareth team to develop a broad understanding of the situation of the SM by the Nazareth team and a similar understanding of the principles, practices, data bases, analytic approaches, instruments and outcomes of the Nazareth model. The objective of this workshop will be to provide the framework for a detailed design of the development of the program. The SM will identify with the Nazareth team, the information and resource gaps that
 Annex 6 Page 2 of 4 would need to be filled, as well as critical contextual circumstances that would influence the design of a system suitable to and sustainable by, the SM. The expertise and activities necessary to fill the gaps and a tentative timetable for these activities would be an important output. Further inputs desired from the Nazareth team also would be identified. 5. The WG would initiate the preparation activities for the maintenance program on the basis of the outcome of this workshop. In planning for this maintenance program, the WG will define modules of activity that may be initiated as soon as possible and as these modules are prepared, with the assistance of consultants financed under this project, they would be implemented, also with project financing. Successive modules would be initiated until a complete program is prepared and implemented. 6. To facilitate the objective of designing a national program based on the experiences of the SMs, they would inform the Management Technical Committee at each stage of the development of the program, of the process followed, its outcomes and the resulting plans. The Management Technical Committee, with the help of their consultants, will synthesize the lessons learned into a set of guidelines and training programs for the other municipalities and agencies responsible for maintenance of local infrastructure. In addition, the Committee will oversee the preparation of a national program for maintenance to be presented to donors, for their support. 7. The Nazareth Model. The remainder of this annex outlines some indicative elements of this Nazareth model. The following features underlay the design and operations of the Nazareth maintenance program: a) Maintenance planning begins with infrastructure systems and project design and implementation. As a result, standards and specifications that are developed for works are influenced by their maintenance implications, and the operating life and performance characteristics of components and materials are used to develop maintenance plans and schedules. To ensure that standards are met, implementation is supervised by qualified professional staff of the municipality. b) Specific strategies are developed for preventative maintenance, which is designed to reduce failures of systems components and resulting loss of services; and repairs, which address failures that do occur. c) Public and private sector roles are assigned according to the comparative advantages of each and in such a manner as to reduce overall costs and improve performance. d) Public education and responsiveness to the public is a critical and integral part of the program. 8. Examples of these principles applied to the services of water supply, wastewater disposal and roads as described below: Water Design, Construction and Supervision: In order to have a balanced system that does not result in undue pressures in some areas and partially filled pipes in others, both of which conditions contribute to failures, Nazareth is divided into eight pressure zones based on topography and it
 Annex 6 Page 3 of 4 is planned to have a reservoir for each pressure zone. Three types of pipes and installation methods for household connections are utilized depending on the terrain and soil conditions. In mountainous areas, with rocky soils, steel pipes are used and covered in concrete; where soil conditions are amenable, pipes are covered in plastic; and, in softer soils steel with asphalt cover is installed. Projects are supervised according to size; big projects are supervised by both consultants and municipality staff, plus periodic inspections by the Chief Engineer. Welded pipes are x-rayed and pressure tested; they must have been welded by a licensed welder. This procedure results in an average life of 22-25 years. Maintenance Planning: Contractors must provide as built drawings to the municipalities for documentation purposes and all buildings must file plans with them so that the location of lines are known. Programs of protection or replacement are planned for pipes, depending on the conditions. Plans for replacements also are coordinated with road upgrading. Structure plans are prepared and updated regularly. Annual reviews determine which pipes are to be replaced as a result of age. Meters are changed every five years. Private Sector Participation: The responsibility for the replacement of large pipes is assigned to contractors who are on call, having been selected and assigned according to pre-established zones in the city. This clearly minimizes the staff and equipment for this purpose that would be necessary for the municipallty to keep. Pumps are maintained under contract for similar reasons. Repairs and Responsiveness to the Public: The maintenance groups work sixteen hours a day, in two shifts, in order to ensure that the 125 monthly repair calls are fixed the same day that the complaints are received. The critical aspect of the strategy for repairs is to minimize response time, and secondly to reduce losses to the municipality. This has resulted in a policy of instituting temporary relief measures when immediate repairs are not possible. When a complaint is received, an inspector is dispatched to determine need (unless it is already known that excavation will be necessary, in which case that team goes immediately). The inspector (or excavation team) radios in the (other) requirements, and the necessary team follows. Staff training emphasizes fixing it right, first time. Wastewater Routine maintenance: Pipes are flushed at least once a year, before winter, and once more during winter for known trouble spots. In some areas, culverts are closed during the summer to prevent dumping of materials in them. Staff are trained to recognize warning signs of problems and must inspect for them; when lines are blocked and when culverts are being cleaned potential and current repair needs are identified. There is a systematic program for opening of manhole covers and inspection of lines. Roads Maintenance planning: Each road has its own documentation and ongoing expenditure account. The system tracks the remaining life of a road to determine the appropriate maintenance activity. The estimated life of a new or completely renovated road is about eight or nine years, and the effects of asphalting, overlays and renovation on extending the life of the road is calculated and assessed along with other known conditions such as accumulated expenditure since last major
 Annex 6 Page 4 of 4 works, traffic type and volume. In addition, plans for road excavation for water works are reviewed. On this basis, the appropriate action is scheduled. Daily inspections also identify areas for asphalting. Private sector involvement: Annually, a book of contracts for all maintenance work to be done is prepared and qualified contractors are invited to bid for these works. These contractors are then on call throughout the year to provide the appropriate services to the municipality at the bid price. This facilitates the planning and budgeting of the municipality, decreases the response time for work to be initiated and allows more flexible appropriate scheduling. Public Education and Involvement 9. The municipality has created a rapid response center to field citizen complaints and reports on maintenance or repairs needed. This center has toll-free hotline services manned 24 hours a day, backed by crews at work 16 hours a day and on-call duty during the remaining eight hours. The number of these hotlines and other urgent numbers are mailed annually with the utilities bills. The public is alerted by public education programs to provide critical information when calling hotlines. These include location, (with street lights, the number on the electricity pole), the manifestation of the problem, and the action taken, if any. By the municipality responding quickly to these calls the public has learned that it is worthwhile to utilize this facility. As a result, the cost to the municipality and the public of systems failures has been greatly reduced. Studies and Guidelines 10. The Nazareth program has carried out a number of studies related to maintenance in order to determine the most beneficial strategies. In addition, the professional associations in the sectors have disseminated experience and recommended specifications for equipment and procedures that have been helpful in planning and management of maintenance.

 Annex 8 Appendix A Performance Indicators, Performance Standards and Input Guidelines Establishing a System of Accountability 1. Central ministries will need to establish indicators that signal whether policies are having intended effects. These performance indicators will usually be based on the cumulative effect of achieving standards of output from related service delivery systems within a sector. For example, the proposed performance indicator for the water supply sector is increased per capita consumption of water. This indicator captures the effect of lower relative prices to consumers, greater availability and access to water, greater reliability of service delivery, better quality of product and public increased understanding of, and participation in, the service operations and benefits. The performance standards for the delivery systems that relates to these intended effects include the level of unaccounted for water, the number and timing of interruptions in service, the duration of interruptions, and bill collection percentage. 2. In establishing performance standards, the ministries also should provide contextual guidelines about input and procedures and examples of best, or at least good practice, so that local governments will have the basis for assessing their own situation and designing the most feasible approach to achieving the policy objectives under their particular circumstances. It is in the establishment of performance standards that the system of accountability starts. In many cases, standard procedures based on proven experience will be readily replicable, however, there undoubtedly will be many other cases where local governments will have to evolve creative solutions. Policy structures will have to consider both sets of possibilities. Policy Implementation 3. Implementing policy in the context of decentralization involves convincing the people in local communities, through their leadership, of the utility of the policy prescription to them. As a consequence, local leaders and officials must be educated to the values and validity of the policies and programs suggested to achieve their objectives. Perhaps the best way of accomplishing this task is to give local governments the tools and the opportunity to convince themselves. In some cases, this may involve helping the local governments to carry out studies and prepare plans for the sector in their jurisdiction; quite often, this may be accomplished through training. If the preparation of plans and programs within the local governments involves real participation of its commnunities, then these communities in turn become knowledgeable about the policies and what outcomes they should expect from the services of the sector. Knowledgeable communities contribute substantially to the successful implementation of policy; insofar as they hold their local agencies and their leadership accountable for achieving known performance standards, they become a vital part of the overall system of accountability. Performance Monitoring and Reporting 4. MLG and the technical ministries must monitor the movement of the performance indicators for their sectors and the achievement of the related performance standards by district agencies. This monitoring serves several useful functions: it allows the ministry to report to the country on progress vis- a-vis its mandate, thus, in the example of the water supply sector, it would mean reporting on the increase or decrease in consumption, as that indicator summarizes the outcome of all related efforts to advance the sector. It allows comparative assessment of, and reporting on, the performance of local governments with regard to the aspects for which they are responsible. Other components of the policy implementation system such as extending services to the poor would be reported on, and analyzing the performance of the various components may indicate particular weaknesses in the policy framework that need to be addressed, and may indicate where research is needed.
 Annex 8 Appendix A 5. It should therefore be clear that performance monitoring and reporting is the vital core of accountability. A complete picture of performance includes an assessment of the inputs that went into achieving that level of output. The traditional concern only with tracking (especially financial) inputs, is limited even under centralized systems. It is less than helpful under decentralization. The incentives to use resources wisely and efficiently at the local government level must come from reinforcing responsiveness to communities at every level - among local officials, local political leaders and the central government. A scorecard that is open, transparent and available to all provides substantial incentives to improvement, and that may be the greatest benefit of accountability. It is important to note that the approach described here does not require or involve the central government intruding on the responsibility and authority of the local governments. Policy implementation includes ensuring that the role of the local governments, the basis on which their performance is evaluated and how their accomplishments compared to others, is well understood by their constituents. With that understanding, the pressure to improve local government performance should come from constituents - where it belongs. Training 6. As noted earlier, training is an important mechanism by which central ministries may assist local governments to perform their roles and functions. Training also may be a vehicle for selling local governments on the policies and programs of a sector. However, the approach to training and the development of training programs need to be responsive to different circumstances. Staff within the command structure of a ministry may be directed to undergo training. Further, the incentives of training in that context may be entirely within the control of the ministry. Training between MLG and local government staff must employ new strategies. Training must be seen as helping local governments accomplish their objectives; as such, local governments must be consulted about the training to be provided and how it is to be delivered. It is appropriate and useful for MLG to prepare initial menus of potential training opportunities based on their observations of what are the critical issues faced in policy implementation at the municipal local level or below. However, it is recommended that local governments have a substantial input in determining the priority of offerings. It also is useful to have consultations with a selection of local government staff on the focus and presentation of training events. Like other programs, training should have performance indicators and standards which are monitored and the results published.

 Annex 12 Appendix A The Ministry of Local Government (MLG) 1. This ministry is responsible for both the implementation of EAPC policy at the local levels and the representation of local government issues at the central level. As is the case with most newly established central bodies, MLG has been striving to establish a viable role for itself within its mandate, with mixed success. The ministry has promoted a number of village councils to municipal status and the smaller and weaker municipalities appear to look to the ministry for support, assistance and guidance, however, the bigger and more capable municipalities worry that MLG intrudes unduly into their sphere of authority. The ambiguity of the legal situation and other factors (discussed in Annex 2) have no doubt contributed to this unease, nevertheless, there are reasons to believe that roles acceptable to the various interests may readily be negotiated. Among these reasons are the relatively small size of the ministry, which precludes a pervasive intrusive role by the MLG and the strong core of its leadership which is oriented towards building more autonomous local governments. 2. The total staff of the ministry is 134 persons (60% technical and professional and 40% administrative) distributed among the leadership core and its staff functions, five central line departments and thirteen provincial offices (see Chart 4 Appendix A on the next page). The Finance and Administration Department is divided into two sections, one responsible for MLG's own establishment and financial affairs and the other responsible for audits and inspections of accounts of the local governments. The Inspectorate and Follow-up Department is responsible for broad performance monitoring and for the establishment of new village councils and municipalities. The Planning and Zoning Department prepares plans for areas outside of municipalities, but also appears to have some responsibility for the plans of municipalities. The Engineering Department is responsible for the review of local and regional infrastructure projects. There is potential overlap in the responsibilities of this department with those of other central agencies such as PECDAR and the Ministries of Transportation and Works; this is an issue to be resolved under the framework proposed by this project. A Research and Development Department is planned but is not yet fully functioning. The provincial level offices are intended to have representatives of the central departments at that level, thus approximately 13-15 staff are proposed for each such office, however, these are currently, lightly staffed (about 3 or 4 staff each). 3. In view of current budgetary constraints, MLG proposes to initiate the capacity building program by establishing an internal committee of the key department heads and chaired by the Deputy Minister to over see the efforts. This committee will have a secretariat with a staff of seven, three and a secretary seconded from existing departments and three consultants hired full time under this project. This arrangement will be reviewed after six months to determine whether addition resources should be added and after a year to determine whether the unit should become part of the MLG establishment.

doc.repnme: West Bank and Gaza - Municipal Infrastructure Development Project
doc.abstracts: The Municipal Infrastructure Development Project seeks to continue the thrusts of the Emergency Rehabilitation Project, but will break new ground by helping to initiate significant institutional reform and capacity building in the local government sector. Specific project objectives, therefore, are: 1) to help remove critical infrastructural bottlenecks; improve essential services and facilities; preserve existing infrastructural assets; and create productive employment; and 2) to strengthen the local government system, particularly to rationalize roles and responsibilities and build finance and managerial capacity. The project will consist of the following components: 1) infrastructure rehabilitation and improvement including: (a) a rehabilitation and improvement sub-program; (b) a maintenance sub-program; and (c) a neighborhood upgrading sub-program; 2) local government reform and capacity building comprising: (a) local government technical assistance and capacity building; and (b) selected municipality technical assistance and capacity building; and 3) managerial support and incremental operating expenses.
